thread.title: COC removes women’s soccer coach Bev Priestman amid Olympic drone spying scandal

title: COC removes women’s soccer coach Bev Priestman amid Olympic drone spying scandal
text:
COC removes women’s soccer coach Bev Priestman amid Olympic drone spying scandal By: The Canadian Press Posted: 6:36 PM CDT Thursday, Jul. 25, 2024 Last Modified: 6:53 PM CDT Thursday, Jul. 25, 2024 Advertisement

PARIS - Bev Priestman's time at the Paris Olympics ended before the opening ceremony.

PARIS – Bev Priestman’s time at the Paris Olympics ended before the opening ceremony.
The Canadian Olympic Committee has removed the head coach of its women’s national soccer head coach for the remainder of the Games amid a drone spying scandal.
The COC added in a statement released at 1:24 a.m. local time that assistant coach Andy Spence will lead the defending gold medallists for the remainder of the tournament.
Canada's head coach Bev Priestman walks along the touch line prior to first half International friendly action against Mexico in Toronto, on Tuesday June 4, 2024. The Canadian Olympic Committee has removed women's soccer head coach Bev Priestman from her role at the Paris Games amid a drone spying scandal. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Chris Young Canada’s camp was thrown into disarray this week after two team staffers were sent home for allegedly using a drone to spy on a New Zealand practice. Priestman denied any involvement, but did not attend Thursday’s 2-1 victory over New Zealand as FIFA — soccer’s world governing body — and the International Olympic Committee investigate.
Canada Soccer CEO and general secretary Kevin Blue said in the COC release “additional information has come to our attention regarding previous drone use against opponents, predating the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.”

Sign up for Business Weekly Sign Up I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies , and CASL agreement . He added Priestman is suspended from her duties until the end of the tournament and the completion of the organization’s independent external review.
This report by The Canadia Press was first published July 25, 2024.
